title: Just how small is the Planck length? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hooboy. The Planck length is… hard to describe, at least in relatable terms. This is mostly because it is so inconceivably tiny, that any attempt at comparison falls flat. To show why, let’s go through a few attempts at comparisons. For reference, the Planck length is [math]~1.6*10^{-36} [/math]meters. First, let’s try taking the solar system and blowing it up to the size of the observable universe. The solar system is about [math]1.[/math][math]45*10^{13}[/math] meters in radius, and the universe clocks in at [math]8.8 * 10^{26}[/math] meters, so this would stretch the Planck length out to… [math]9.7*10^{-23}[/math], or about a billionth the size of an electron. Well, that didn’t get us anywhere. Let’s try just stretching the Earth out to the size of the universe. With the earth at [math]6.3*10^{6}[/math]m, that brings us to just a tenth the size of an electron, or [math]2.23*10^{-16}[/math]m. Still not great, but we’re getting there. Let’s try one last thing. You may have heard the famous comparison “if an atom was the size of a football field, the nucleus would be the width of one blade of grass.” In this comparison, the Planck length would be… even smaller than it was in our first comparison, where the solar system became the universe. But how about we take that one step further. What if instead of taking an atom and making it a football field, we take an football field and make it the size of the entire observable universe? Since we’re using radii, the football field comes in at 50m. Plugging in our values, if we blow up a regulation-size football field to the size of the entire observable universe, the planck length becomes… the size of an atom. The Planck length is small.

Planck length is a fundamental space-time length which could be thought of as the length of the smallest unit of space in the “fabric of space”. It is by calculation 1.616 times 10 to the power -35 m. It is is derived from Planck’s constant, and speed of light and Newton’s universal gravitational constant G. It is a fundamental length of the smallest space unit(can be extended to planck’s area or volume also). It is about 10 to the power 20 times smaller than the diameter of a proton!!!! The concept is being used in string theory now, where it could be the space length containing a “string” or possibly a much smaller string(yet unknown), or a collection of much smaller strings(yet unknown), than containing the calculated length of a said “string” only which is much larger, in the order of 10^-33(10 to the power -33/about 100 times the planck’s length). Overall Planck length has been reasonably well defined. What is more universally made use of is Planck’s constant. It is in the order of 10^-34 or 10 to the power -34. The exact value of planck’s constant is 6.626 times 10 to the power -34 m^2kg/s(or Joule.s). You can have some idea of what it is when you look at the Planck-Einstein energy equation for a photon: E=hf, where E stands for energy of the photon, f stands for the frequency of light, and h is planck’s universal constant. So solving for h gives you h=E/f, which has the dimension of J.s, or joule.second. Please note that recent advances in superstring theory predict that a string’s length(in considerstion) is in the order of 10 to the power -33, roughly about 10 times bigger than planck’s unviersal constant’s dimension, and 100 times bigger than the calculated planck length. The latter may suggest existence of much smaller and more fundamental ‘strings’ than what has been postulated to exist… Kaiser T, MD (Life long physics, math, cosmology, and science proponent).
